title: GCS-Pupils Score
description: The GCS-Pupils Score (GCS-P) combines the Glasgow Coma Scale with pupillary reactivity assessment to provide enhanced prognostic accuracy in traumatic brain injury patients. This extended index offers improved prediction of 6-month mortality and unfavorable outcomes, particularly in patients with severe brain injury where standard GCS may be limited.

result.name: gcs_pupils_score
result.description: Combined GCS-Pupils score with mortality and outcome predictions

ranges.interpretation: Extremely severe brain injury with very high mortality risk (>64%) and unfavorable outcome probability (>85%). Requires intensive neurological monitoring and aggressive supportive care. Consider goals of care discussions with family.
Severe brain injury with high mortality risk (25-40%) and substantial unfavorable outcome probability (46-69%). Intensive neurological monitoring and comprehensive rehabilitation planning essential.
Moderate brain injury with intermediate mortality risk (17-20%) and moderate unfavorable outcome probability (30-37%). Close neurological monitoring and early rehabilitation intervention recommended.
Mild to moderate brain injury with lower mortality risk (9-17%) and reduced unfavorable outcome probability (20-29%). Monitor for complications and initiate appropriate rehabilitation.
Mild brain injury with low mortality risk (3-7%) and favorable outcome probability (>84%). Monitor for post-concussive symptoms and ensure appropriate follow-up.

references: Brennan PM, Murray GD, Teasdale GM. Simplifying the use of prognostic information in traumatic brain injury. Part 1: The GCS-Pupils score: an extended index of clinical severity. J Neurosurg. 2018;128(6):1612-1620. doi: 10.3171/2017.12.JNS172780.
Teasdale G, Maas A, Lecky F, et al. The Glasgow Coma Scale at 40 years: standing the test of time. Lancet Neurol. 2014;13(8):844-54. doi: 10.1016/S1474-4422(14)70120-6.

Steyerberg EW, Mushkudiani N, Perel P, et al. Predicting outcome after traumatic brain injury: development and international validation of prognostic scores based on admission characteristics. PLoS Med. 2008;5(8):e165. doi: 10.1371/journal.pmed.0050165.
formula: GCS-P = GCS Total Score + Pupil Reactivity Score, where GCS = Eye Response + Verbal Response + Motor Response, and Pupil Reactivity Score: Both reactive = 0 points, One unreactive = 1 point, Both unreactive = 2 points
notes: The GCS-Pupils score extends the range of prognostic information beyond standard GCS alone
Particularly valuable in patients with very low GCS scores (3-4) where pupillary reactivity adds significant prognostic value
Mortality and outcome predictions are based on 6-month follow-up data from IMPACT and CRASH databases
Unfavorable outcome is defined as death, vegetative state, or severe disability at 6 months
The score provides a continuous relationship between injury severity and outcomes
Should be used in conjunction with other clinical factors and imaging findings for comprehensive assessment
Regular reassessment is important as neurological status may change over time
Consider cultural and communication factors when assessing verbal response in non-English speakers
